Name: Fletcherism
Summary: A diet proposed by Horace Fletcher that advocates for chewing all bites of food at least 200 times for improved digestion.

Name: First Food Guide
Summary: “Food for Young Children” and “How to Select Food”

Name: Calorie Counting
Summary: A dieting methodology popularized by Dr. Lulu Hunt Peters in the book “Diet and Health: With Key to the Calories.” The describes how weight gain can be prevented by not consuming a caloric excess and makes the process accessible by including tables of calorie values for common foods.

Name: Hay Diet
Summary: A diet proposed by physician William Hay that introduces the concept of appropriate food “combinations.” Foods are grouped into protein, starch, and neutral categories, and the diet suggests that for improved digestions and weight-loss, proteins and starches should not be consumed in the same meal while neutrals could be consumed with either.

Name: Discovery of Cyclamate
Summary: Cyclamate, the chemical behind the “Sweet’N Low” zero-calorie artificial sweetener is discovered at the University of Illinois. It is used to sweeten diet soft drinks.

Name: The Basic Seven
Summary: A guide recommending the number of servings of each of seven identified food groups, without defining a serving size. Considered overly complex.

Name: Fat Rationing
Summary: Since they can be used to make explosives and America is in the middle of World War II, the government begins a fat rationing program to save fats for military use.

Name: World War II Ends
Summary: World War II ends and the fat rationing program is stopped along with it.

Name: Food for Fitness
Summary: Simplified guide grouping food into four groups and specifying recommended consumption of each.

Name: Seven Countries Study
Summary: Dr. Ancel Keys begins the Seven Countries Study, which is the first proposal of the link between saturated fat consumption and negative health outcomes. This has far-reaching effects on nutrition research as a whole and even influences the 1984 federal dietary guidelines.

Name: Low-Fat Diet
Summary: The idea of a diet low in fat to improve general health begins to gain popularity among the overall populace—not just heart disease patients for whom it was originally thought to be helpful.

Name: Discovery of Aspertame
Summary: Aspertame, the low-calorie artificial sweetener behind Nutrasweet, is accidentally discovered by research chemist James Schlatter during his work in developing an ulcer drug.

Name: Atkins Diet
Summary: A very popular diet proposed by Dr. Robert C. Atkins in his book Dr. Atkins’ Diet Revolution. The diet suggests limiting carbohydrates like grains and sugars while eating larger amounts of fats and protein. This launched years of research into and trends of low-carb dieting, which persist today.

Name: Discovery of Sucralose
Summary: Sucralose, the artificial sweetener marketed as Splenda, is discovered as scientists find a way to create a molecular bond between sucrose and chlorine.

Name: Hassel-Free Food Guide
Summary: Improvement upon the “Basic Four” of 1956, adding a fifth group of foods that should be limited: fats, sweets, and alcohol.

Name: Food Wheel
Summary: Guide with five food groups, with intake goals for nutrient sufficiency. Specifies ranges of amounts of foods to eat to accommodate diets with varying levels of total calories.

Name: Trans Fat Suspicion
Summary: Ronald Mensink and Martijn Katan, dutch researchers, publish a study detailing the negative effects of trans fats on cholesterol.

Name: Food Guide Pyramid
Summary: Overhaul of past food guides based on consumer research. Focuses on variety, moderation, and proportion, and shows where added fats and sugars may be lurking in each food group.

Name: MyPyramid
Summary: An updated pyramid intended to be simpler to understand. Identifies oil independently from other foods due to rising consumption and alludes to the importance of physical activity.

Name: MyPlate
Summary: An update to the food pyramid that recommends similar portions but describes them through a plate metaphor. This is thought to be more easily understood as it directly shows the proportion of foods recommended on a plate for each meal.
